Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Geoprivacy Attitudes and Personal Location-Masking Strategies of Internet Users

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine public attitudes towards geoprivacy and the extent to which Internet users attempt to obscure or mask their personal locations in order to protect privacy when they engage in online activity. The project will provide new knowledge about the strategies individuals employ to prevent their personal identifiability when location is requested, and it will provide new insights into the relationships between privacy attitudes and behavior in responding to location requests. While much work on geoprivacy focuses on strategies for researchers to protect the anonymity of human subjects, this project will emphasize the role individuals play in managing their own location profiles. This project will enhance basic understanding of the factors associated with the propensity to mask location, which will inform future research that assumes self-reported location to be factual by providing a sounder basis for error calculation. Improved knowledge about who is masking their data online and why they are doing so will help application developers better understand how to serve those individuals. Results will be disseminated broadly to a wide range of potential beneficiaries, including non-profit groups that seek to protect digital privacy and governmental organizations like the National Geospatial Advisory Committee. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Geoprivacy refers to the right of individuals to control when and how their personal location data are shared. Amid increasingly pervasive locational data collection, attempts by the public to exercise this control largely remain unexplored. This doctoral student conducting this project will examine the ways in which adults mask their location data online as well as how geoprivacy knowledge and attitudes influence this location-masking behavior. She will conduct an online survey of adults in California using a probability sample with a mail contact method to enhance response rate and an open sample with an online solicitation. She will analyze the correlates of both the resolution and factuality of location provided in the survey with logistic regression. Among intervening variables that the student will consider are previous privacy infringement, experience with hacking or identity theft, and data industry experience. She also will test for spatial clusters of higher and lower levels of location-masking activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to examine public attitudes towards geoprivacy and measure the prevalence of personal-level location masking behavior among internet users. Examples of such masking behavior include purposefully obscuring location, such as by providing an inaccurate address, altering IP address, or limiting the use of smartphone location services. This goal was achieved using a statewide California survey measuring the ways in which adults obscure their locations when responding to location requests, and capturing information on geoprivacy-related knowledge and attitudes.

A main achievement of this project was the deployment of a web-based survey to two samples within California, one a probability address-based sample, and the other an open online sample. The survey received 214 responses overall and provided some of the first known estimates of location-masking behavior at the individual level. In both samples, 15% of respondents reported that they intentionally provided incorrect address information in response to a location request within the survey, and 10% of respondents reported that they deliberately moved a map pin away from their home locations. The survey also revealed new information on geoprivacy-related knowledge. For instance, 50% of respondents knew that GPS is not the only means by which location can be collected on a smartphone, and 73% knew that that an IP address can be used to collect location data. A key attitude significantly correlated with the propensity to mask location is a lack of trust in websites to protect personal data. Location masking behavior takes place across demographic lines, with no significant differences by ethnicity, age, income, sex, educational attainment, or urban locations.

This project demonstrates that it is not only data stewards who aim to protect privacy through location masking; obscuring location is also a privacy-protective practice employed by individuals. By highlighting the agency of individuals to protect their geoprivacy and the contexts in which they do so, privacy education campaigns can be better targeted to foster societal adoption of geoprivacy tools. This study likewise provides a new understanding of the factors associated with the propensity to mask location, which include knowledge about how location is shared and privacy-concerned attitudes. The results of the survey corroborate the hypothesis that adults attempt to protect their location privacy through personal location-masking strategies, and demonstrates that they do so across sociodemographic groups. The results also provide an estimate or error for self-reported location data in other survey instruments, particularly those in which respondents enter text in separate address fields or move a point in a map interface.

Results of this project were shared widely with the academic community at three major conferences: the 2017 Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2017), the 2018 American Association of Geographers (AAG) Annual Meeting, and the 10th International Conference on Geographic Information Science (GIScience 2018).  Preliminary results of the survey were published in the conference proceedings for GIScience 2018, and an additional manuscript with the full survey results was submitted to the Annals of the American Association of Geographers. The project funding also led to the successful completion and public defense of a doctoral dissertation by the co-PI, as well as helped her establish a strong independent research career.

Additional outcomes of this project include the distribution of educational materials and resources for location privacy, which were provided to all 214 participants of the survey. The web-based survey deployed in this project necessitated the custom development of an interactive map interface. The code for integrating this map feature, which was programmed in Leaflet JavaScript for the Qualtrics survey platform, was made publicly available by the PIs. Project results were further distributed to the communities of interest in the form of a research summary document, which was shared with two major privacy non-profit groups, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC). A summary of research was also shared with the National Geospatial Advisory Committee (NGAC). In support of future data use and in correspondence with our data management plan, the anonymized survey data were deposited in the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) repository hosted by the University of Michigan.
